## GAD-7 vs CTS

GAD-7 vs CTS When comparing the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Conflict Tactics Scale (CTS), it's important to note that these instruments serve distinct purposes and target different facets of human psychological experiences. GAD-7 primarily focuses on the identification and severity of generalised anxiety disorder symptoms, whilst CTS is designed to quantify the occurrence and severity of different forms of domestic violence. The challenging part comes when trying to harmonize these questionnaires, especially finding correlating or overlapping items. By utilising advanced software like Harmony, the process of comparing GAD-7 vs CTS becomes significantly lighter. Harmony employs natural language processing and generative AI models to harmonize different questionnaires, including GAD-7 and CTS. Recognizing similarities between unrelated items or judging the degree of match is made possible with Harmony's sophisticated technology. Whatâ€™s more? Harmony also enables comparisons in multiple languages, enhancing researchers' capability to conduct comprehensive and progressive studies. The GAD-7 vs CTS comparison with a stress-free harmonization process using Harmony creates a conducive atmosphere for psychologists and social scientists to bear relevant results, regardless of the studies' nature. Using Harmony for GAD-7 vs CTS comparison gives researchers a clearer and more focused lens in analyzing data, eventually leading to impactful and socially-relevant study outcomes. As a tool, Harmony not only lightens workload but also guarantees a high-quality, efficient, and reliable questionnaire harmonization process.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
